s.text: What's occasioned the most notice, fittingly enough, was Greenspan's argument that central bankers needed to pay attention to asset prices--like, oh, the stock market--in addition to the prices of normal goods and services if the bankers want to have a handle on what may drive inflation in the future.
What's especially curious about this is that one would have thought this was a conclusion a supposedly ardent devotee of the free market would have reached a long time ago.
